entry.title: What’s New in SAP HANA Cloud – September 2025
entry.content:
What’s New in SAP HANA Cloud – September 2025

As we approach the end of the third quarter of 2025, we are thrilled to present the third release of SAP HANA Cloud for the year. Certainly, this quarterly update brings many innovative features designed to enhance your experience with SAP HANA Cloud and drive business value.



Let’s explore the exciting new capabilities and improvements that have just been made available.

 

Innovations in SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database

Administration and Service Management

Bulk Alert configuration

Starting off strong, the Q3 release introduces bulk alert configuration. Building on previous alert configuration methods and REST API-based bulk management, alert rule sets offer a graphical interface for bulk alert configuration accessible to all administrators without API expertise. The feature also allows to create and save alert configuration templates, making it easy to reuse them across different instances.

Bulk alert configuration significantly enhances user efficiency by streamlining the alert setup process. Management of complex alert configurations becomes more scalable, while safeguarding that all instances are monitored effectively without the need for repetitive manual setup.

To learn more about this new feature, take a look at this blog post by our product expert Hai Zhang.  

Partition Advisor

The Recommendation App, housing all intelligent advisors for SAP HANA Cloud, hosts a new advisor, as we introduce the partition advisor with QRC3 2025. It helps maintain manageable partition sizes by automatically analyzing potential partition keys and methods (range versus hash). It provides recommendations on how to partition your data effectively and can apply these recommendations via an “Apply” button to your tables.

The Partition Advisor saves time by automating the analysis of partitioning options and delivering actionable recommendations. It helps users identify tables that may exceed the limits, suggesting optimal repartitioning strategies. This not only improves query performance but also optimizes costs, ensuring that your data management remains efficient and scalable.

Find more information about the partition advisor in this help documentation. 

Support for 9 TB instances on Microsoft Azure

From now on, SAP HANA Cloud on Microsoft Azure supports large instances up to 9TB. Please note that the availability of these large database instances will vary depending on your selected region.

With the support for 9 TB instances on Azure, businesses gain the flexibility to scale up their databases as needed. It allows them to handle increased memory requirements, while ensuring that their database can keep pace with growing data demands. This scalability is crucial for maintaining optimal performance and supporting business growth.

Finding object dependencies in database objects

Dependencies are now shown in the properties page of schema objects such as tables, views, functions, and procedures in the database objects app.  This enables you to quickly examine the dependencies between objects. 

As seen below in the Database Objects app, the table CUSTOMER has an incoming referential dependency from the RESERVATION table and is referenced in a view and function.  A graphical dependency viewer is also available in the SAP HANA database explorer extension in SAP Business Application Studio or Visual Studio Code. 

Simplified Instance Provisioning

The SAP HANA Cloud provisioning wizard has been enhanced to enable users to select either a preset configuration, provide a JSON configuration, or to use a manual configuration when creating new instances. 


The preset configurations for SAP HANA databases include basic, minimum, maximum, last used, and most used, enabling a user to quickly choose a preset that closely matches their use case.  After filling in a few required fields such as instance name and password, the instance can be created.  Basic is sized to support additional features such as the document store, triple store, natural language processing, and the script and data provisioning servers.   

The JSON configuration option enables a user to create instances based on a JSON document that contains the settings of the instance.  This can be helpful if you wish to create multiple instances with very similar configurations. 

Finally, the manual configuration option enables a user to explore all the possible configuration setting using the instance wizard. 

 

SQL Console statement library

With the QRC3 release of SAP HANA Cloud, the statement library in the SQL Console of SAP HANA Cloud Central has the option to run and open multiple statements either in the current tab or in individual tabs.   

Run will append the statements together and the results will be shown in separate result set tabs. 

Run in Individual Tabs opens each selected statement in its own SQL Console tab and executes it. 

Data Integration

Introducing the New Data Access Agent - connecting to Azure SQL Database & Snowflake

Additionally, I am thrilled to announce that SAP HANA smart data access (SDA) now supports Microsoft Azure SQL database and Snowflake as remote sources via the new Data Access Agent. This new Data Access Agent expands data federation and provides broader coverage with JDBC-based adapters as an SAP-managed service.

With a clean core strategy in mind, SDA is a core component to leverage the full potential of your data. Until recently, the limited protocol boundaries to ODBC and REST as well as restrictions on running 3rd party drivers, limited the supported scope of remote resources. SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) helped to bridge this gap but required customers to deploy and operate the Data Provisioning Agent (DPAgent) in an on-premise setup.

The new Data Access Agent now supports new JDBC-based adapters. Of course, the natively available SDA adapters continue to be based on ODBC and REST. The SAP-managed Data Access Agent simplifies operations and reduces the effort to access Microsoft Azure SQL Database and the Snowflake in SAP HANA Cloud. Users can also benefit from streamlined and user-friendly configuration and monitoring of this fully managed, secure, and cloud native product.

Please note the new Data Access Agent currently only supports data federation and snapshot toggling within the virtual table interface. Real-time replication is not supported. Refer to further details of support in SAP Note 2600176 - SAP HANA Smart Data Access Supported Remote Sources.

To learn more about SAP HANA Cloud's New Data Access Agent, take a look at @SeungjoonLee 's  blog post here.

Support a remote source to SharePoint in Microsoft 365 

Moreover, with the Q3 release we introduce support for creating a remote source to SharePoint in Microsoft 365 using the data access agent of SAP HANA smart data access. This feature allows for the virtualization of data, including lists and Excel worksheets, within SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database. For further details on supported remote sources, refer to SAP Note 2600176.

With the ability to access SharePoint data in Microsoft 365 through the SAP-managed data access agent, users can simplify operations and reduce the effort required for data integration. This eventually enhances collaboration and streamlines data management processes.

Direct SQL access to files in the Apache Iceberg open table format

Furthermore, with the recent release we introduce direct SQL access to files in the Apache Iceberg’s open table format. This enhancement enables users to create virtual tables within SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database, allowing read-only access to Apache Iceberg data in external object storage. Supported storage types include the data lake files in SAP HANA Cloud, Amazon S3, Azure Blob Storage, Azure Data Lake Storage (ADLS) Gen2, and Google Cloud Storage.

This means users can execute SQL queries on large volumes of data without the need to load it into the memory of the SAP HANA database. The new feature thus enhances performance and efficiency, enabling seamless data analysis across diverse storage environments.

Security

Row-level data access control over fact tables based on associated dimension attributes

Next, SAP HANA Cloud now supports row-level data access control over fact tables based on associated dimension attributes. This allows users to restrict access to fact table data without the need to join the dimension tables where the access control is applied. Restrictions are based on the availability of associated dimensional data, which is already restricted with a structured filter (=nested structured filters).

This capability enables fine-grain access control to restrict data for fact tables based on associated dimension table attribute data. This enhances security and ensures that sensitive data is accessible only to authorized users, improving overall data governance.

Support for X509-based dynamic user creation

Moreover, SAP HANA Cloud also supports X509-based dynamic user creation, leveraging the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP). Customers can now create user data automatically in SAP HANA Cloud based on X509 authentication and manage user data within related LDAP groups.

Bridging the gap for automated user creation through X509 authentication with user authorization through LDAP, this feature allows for the automation of user creation. This strengthens operational efficiency and streamlines user management processes, ensuring a seamless integration of security protocols.

Support for Azure Private Link

Over the past quarters, there have already been announcements about different private IP endpoint service deliveries. From Q3 2025 on, SAP HANA Cloud now supports Azure Private Link as well, enabling users to connect applications running within an Azure landscape to SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database using private IP endpoints. These endpoints are addressable only within the Azure network and are not exposed publicly, ensuring an additional layer of security. It is important to note that services in SAP HANA Cloud already enforce strict transport layer security (TLS) and allow users to configure IP allow or disallow lists.

With Azure Private Link support, users can significantly reduce the exposure of IP endpoints, enhancing the overall security of connections to SAP HANA Cloud. This feature complements existing IP allow or disallow list filtering, ensuring that sensitive data remains protected and secure within the Azure network.

Multi-Model Data Processing

Vector Embedding SQL Function Support for Generative AI Hub

With the recent release, SAP HANA Cloud once again expands its vector embedding support by allowing the VECTOR_EMBEDDING SQL function to directly use embedding models exposed via SAP GenAI Hub. 

Previously, the function only supported SAP-provided NLP models. Now, customers can connect their own SAP GenAI Hub service instance and consume any available embedding model, for example OpenAI, Amazon Titan, or other partner models directly via SQL. 

All one must do is:

  • Create a remote source in SAP HANA Cloud that points to your SAP GenAI Hub (AI Core) service instance 
  • Configure certificates and authentication controls 
  • Retrieve available models with GET_REMOTE_SOURCE_AI_MODELS built-in procedure 
  • Call VECTOR_EMBEDDING by passing the text, type (e.g. DOCUMENT), model name and version, and the remote source 

For detailed setup and examples, see here. 

Support for Batch Embedding Creation using CREATE VECTOR EMBEDDINGS

SAP HANA Cloud also introduces a newly built-in procedure CREATE_VECTOR_EMBEDDINGS that makes it easier to generate vector embeddings for large volumes of text data stored in SAP HANA tables. Instead of having to process documents row by row, this procedure lets you embed text in batches. You simply provide the table and column that contain your documents, specify the target vector column, choose the NLP model, and the procedure automatically generates embeddings where they are missing. 

This new capability simplifies and accelerates the integration of AI and NLP use cases with SAP HANA Cloud, by reducing time to value for building intelligent applications with embeddings and by allowing developers to process large datasets more efficiently with built-in batch handling. It also eliminates repetitive boilerplate code for embedding creation and storage. 

To summarize, this makes SAP HANA Cloud a more powerful foundation for scenarios such as semantic search, generative AI, and intelligent text analysis. For detailed syntax and examples, see here. 

JSON as a datatype in the SAP HANA Cloud JSON Document Store

With QRC3 2025, SAP HANA Cloud introduces JSON as a datatype in the Document Store. This is not a column data type for tables, but a return type for collections in the Document Store. 

Collections can now return JSON directly instead of NVARCHAR, so queries follow JSON semantics without extra casting. This brings clearer path access with the $ root specifier, better performance through filter and function pushdown, and simpler syntax when working with JSON content. 

By making JSON a first class return type, SAP HANA Cloud improves both efficiency and consistency when building applications on flexible document data. For detailed syntax and examples, see here.

Please note, the ‘$’ document root specifier is mandatory for collections returning JSON. Existing collections will still default to NVARCHAR unless explicitly created or altered to return JSON. Some casts (like TO_NVARCHAR on complex types) are restricted for JSON return types.  

Graphical View Modeling

The third release in 2025 again brings many enhancements to SAP HANA Cloud’s graphical view modeling capabilities. Below, we are giving an overview about the innovations introduced. To get more details, you can take a closer look at Jan Zwickel's blog post.

Ability to rename multiple already mapped columns

Let’s start with the new ability to rename multiple columns that are already mapped, allowing users to perform this action in a single step. This feature is available for star joins and in the node mapping dialog.

This new capability simplifies the refactoring of column names and enhances model insights by enabling users to provide more-specific and meaningful column names. This increases the clarity and usability of data models, improving overall user experience.

Flexibly maintaining labels for alias names

Additionally, users can now flexibly maintain labels for alias names by using expressions. For example, users can generate a label that transforms the alias name to lowercase and adds a prefix.

This feature not only increases development efficiency and improves model quality but also provides a better analytics user experience by ensuring that labels are consistent and meaningful, eventually enhancing the readability and interpretability of data models.

Support of semijoin functionality

Furthermore, the semijoin functionality is now available. This feature enables users to effectively reduce records based on filter values by providing a dedicated join option for filtering in standard join nodes.

The semijoin functionality optimizes resource consumption when filtering through joins, allowing users to more efficiently manage data processing tasks. It enhances performance and ensures that only relevant data is processed, leading to improved overall efficiency and resource utilization.

Switching between structured privileges and structured filters through a graphical editor

Next, we introduced the capability to switch between structured privileges and structured filters using a graphical editor. Users can now change from one object type to another seamlessly and store the changes accordingly.

This increases flexibility when creating analytic privileges, allowing users to easily switch between privilege types to meet their specific requirements. The graphical editor enhances the overall usability and efficiency of managing data insights.

Improved supportability by SQL plan trace for EPM, MDS, and prepared statement caches

Moreover, supportability for SAP HANA Cloud got improved by enabling SQL plan trace for EPM (Enterprise Performance Management) queries, MDS (Multidimensional Services) queries, and prepared statement caches. 

By enabling plan trace for EPM, MDS queries, and prepared statement caches, this feature allows for better troubleshooting and performance analysis. It increases the overall supportability and reliability of these systems, ensuring that users can get the assistance they need when issues arise.

MDS Cubes

Support of input parameters in multidimensional services (MDS) cubes

With the Q3 release, users can now select combinations of input parameter values that will be loaded and served by the MDS cube. This functionality extends the capabilities of MDS cubes, allowing for more flexible and dynamic data insights.

The support for input parameters in MDS cubes increases the scope of scenarios that can be handled, providing users with more comprehensive and tailored insights. Thus, this feature helps users receive insights more quickly, enhancing the overall analytics experience and improving operational efficiency of SAP HANA Cloud.

Using additional currency conversion options with MDS cube

Besides, the recent release enables the use of additional currency conversion options with MDS cubes. Users can now employ rounding, decimal shifts, and the accuracy option "retain all possible digits" in conjunction with MDS cubes.

These additional currency conversion options simplify the creation of MDS cubes from existing calculation views while providing greater flexibility and control over currency data, and ensuring accurate and consistent financial insights.

Using unit conversion of MDS cube measures together with the option to convert at query execution time

Additionally, users are now able to convert units of MDS cube measures during query execution time.

By allowing the unit conversion at query execution time, users gain increased control over when and how unit conversion happens thus enhancing the flexibility and accuracy of data analysis, while also ensuring that units are converted as needed for specific insights.

 

Innovations in SAP HANA Cloud, data lake

Single Sign on support for SAP HANA Cloud, data lake files

The Data Lake Files app in SAP HANA Cloud Central now supports Single Sign-On (SSO) in addition to X509 credentials for authentication.  

It can be enabled with the “Enable Single Sign-On for Data Lake Files” menu item from the actions menu in either the Instances or Data Lake Files app. 

This feature enables users to quickly use the Data Lake Files app without having to do configuration steps required to use X509 authentication. 

 

Further Innovations & Enhancements

SAP HANA Client

Our SAP HANA Client for Python now supports Alpine Linux x64 as of the 2.25 release.  Alpine Linux is a security-oriented, lightweight Linux distribution.  Alpine Linux offers several benefits, such as faster build times due to its lightweight nature and enhanced security with fewer vulnerabilities due to its minimalism.   

However, unlike most Linux distributions, Alpine Linux uses musl libc instead of glibc. While this keeps Alpine lean, it breaks compatibility with the regular Linux x64 SAP HANA Client package and requires its own separate Python wheel release.  It can be found on PyPI at https://pypi.org/project/hdbcli/ 

For further details on the platforms that the SAP HANA Client supports, please see SAP Note 3165810 - SAP HANA Client Supported Platforms 

Expanded Data Center Availability on SAP Cloud Infrastructure in Germany

With QRC3 2025, we are introducing SAP HANA Cloud on SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI) — SAP's own cloud infrastructure, operated in SAP data centers. This new deployment option expands the existing SAP HANA Cloud offering on leading hyperscaler infrastructure (AWS, Azure, GCP, and AliCloud) and meets the growing demand for technological independence, local compliance, and data control. 

Today, SAP HANA Cloud is available on SCI in Frankfurt, Germany. With EU-Access, in-country hosting, and enterprise-grade SLAs, this region offers compliance, security, and reliability for German and European customers. Additional SCI regions are planned for upcoming releases. Check SAP HANA Cloud Data Center Availability in SAP Roadmap Explorer. 

To learn more about SAP HANA Cloud on SCI, take a look at this this blog post.  

Database Application Development

Natural language to SQL generation in Joule using SAP Build Code

Last but not least, we introduce the generation of SQL for SAP HANA Cloud in Joule using SAP Build Code. This feature allows users to generate SQL statements based on natural language input. Additionally, it copies the generated SQL statement to the SQL consoles of the database explorer extension for SAP HANA in SAP Build Code.

This feature increases developer productivity by automating the process of generating SQL statements through natural language input. It reduces the likelihood of errors and improves the quality of the generated SQL, ultimately streamlining the development process and enhancing efficiency.

entry.title: Principal Propagation Setup for HTTPS and RFC (SNC) Protocol from SAP BTP to S/4HANA
entry.content:
Principal Propagation Setup for HTTPS and RFC (SNC) Protocol from SAP BTP to S/4HANA

In this blog, we'll walk through how to configure Principal Propagation from SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) to an on-premises S/4HANA system, using SAP Cloud Connector and SAP Web Dispatcher. We are configuring principal propagation to an S/4HANA system for HTTPS communication and RFC communication using SNC.

References

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/configuring-principal-propagation

About

Principal propagation is the secure process of forwarding a cloud user's identity from a cloud environment to an on-premise system, enabling single sign-on (SSO) and ensuring the user's personal authorizations apply. It relies on a trusted relationship between the cloud and on-premises systems, using mechanisms like JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) or certificates to pass the user's context unchanged, allowing the backend system to recognize the individual user and their permissions.

Scenario: Cloud to On-Premises

  1. A user logs in to the cloud application. Its identity is established by an identity provider (this can be the default IdP for the subaccount or another trusted IdP).
  2. The cloud application then uses a user exchange token (or a designated secondary header) to propagate the user to the Connectivity service. Optionally, the application may use the Destination service to externalize the connection configuration that points to the target on-premise system.
  3. The Connectivity service forwards the JWT (that represents the user) to the Cloud Connector.
  4. The Cloud Connector receives the JWT, verifies it, extracts the attributes, and uses its STS (security token service) component to issue a new token (for example, an X.509 certificate) with the same or similar attributes to assert the identity to the backend (BE1-BEm). The Cloud Connector and the cloud application share the same trust settings.
  5. The Cloud Connector sends the new token (for example, an X.509 certificate) to the backend system.

Pre-requisite

  • Ensure that the SAP Cloud Connector (SCC) is installed and its initial setup has been completed. Refer to the SAP Help documentation.
  • The Cloud Connector should be connected to your SAP BTP subaccount by adding the subaccount details within the SCC. Refer to the SAP Help documentation
  • Additionally, trust must be established between your subaccount and the SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant. This trust setup allows integration with any corporate identity provider and is essential for enabling Single Sign-On (SSO) in your cloud application. Refer to the SAP Help documentation

Configuration Steps

StepsAction Items
1Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for HTTPS
1.1Generate Certificates in SAP Cloud Connector (SCC)
1.2Add Certificates to the SCC Trust Store
1.3Synchronize the cloud trust with Subaccount IDP
1.4Configure SAP S/4HANA for Principal Propagation (HTTPS)
2Configure SAP Web Dispatcher for Principal Propagation
2.1Import Certificates into SAP Web Dispatcher
2.2Maintain Required Parameters in Web Dispatcher
3Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for RFC using SNC
3.1PSE Setup in SAP Cloud Connector for SNC
3.2Configure the S/4HANA System for RFC SNC Propagation
4Create System Mappings in SAP Cloud Connector
4.1Map HTTPS Connections to SAP Web Dispatcher
4.2Map RFC SNC Connections to S/4HANA Backend
5Create Destination in SAP BTP subaccount for HTTPS and RFC SNC scenario

Step 1: Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for HTTPS

Step 1.1: Generate Certificates in SAP Cloud Connector (SCC)

We must configure the following certificates in Cloud Connector:

  • System Certificate
  • CA Certificate
  • User Certificate (Subject Pattern for Principal Propagation)

Note: It is recommended to use signed certificates. Self-signed certificates will also work.

Generating System Certificate

To configure the System Certificate, go to Configuration → On Premise → System Certificate → Create and import a self-signed certificate. Fill the required details in the pop-up window. The Common Name (CN) represents the server’s name protected by the SSL certificate.

Generating CA Certificate

A CA certificate signs all the certificates that are used when a request is forwarded from the Cloud with the Cloud principals.

To create the CA certificate, scroll down to the corresponding section and click on the “Create and import a self-signed certificate” button.

Generating User Certificate

This sample certificate is used to define the rules in the S/4HANA system under the Transaction code (CERTRULE).

Scroll down to the principal propagation section and edit the Subject Pattern Select the Subject Pattern from the list to assert the user IDs. For example, select ${email} to assert the user against the user’s mail address propagated from the Cloud.

click on the Create Sample Certificate button.

Choose an email that already exists on the backend system. Please remember that this is only a sample certificate and will be used to create a rule-based mapping on the backend AS ABAP system

Step 1.2: Add Certificates to the SCC Trust Store

In trust store add below certificates

  • S4HANA SSL server standard
  • Web dispatcher server certificate

Step 1.3: Synchronize the cloud trust with Subaccount IDP

By default, the Cloud Connector does not trust any entries which issues tokens for principal propagation. For this reason, we must establish the trust between the Cloud Connector and the IDP of your subaccount on BTP.

Navigate to the “Cloud to On-Premise” and select the tab Principal Propagation. Click on Synchronise this populate the trust configuration.

Step 1.4: Configure SAP S/4HANA for Principal Propagation (HTTPS)

Now we will do the required configuration in ABAP system.

Step 1.4.a: Import Certificates into the ABAP SSL Server Standard (Transaction: STRUST)

Below certificates need to be imported.

  • cloud connector system certificate imported in s4hana ssl server standard
  • web dispatcher client certificate imported in s4hana ssl server standard

Step 1.4.b: Define Rule-Based Mapping with User Certificate (Transaction: CERTRULE)

Click on the “Import Certificate” button to import the User certificate that was downloaded from the Cloud Connector. In the “Certificate Attr.” choose you attribute mapping from the drop-down menu. In the “Login As” select E-Mail and press enter.

Once you save your new rule you should see a similar screen as below where the “Mapping Status” and “User Status” are both green.

Step 1.4.c: Maintain Reverse Proxy and other parameters in the Default Profile (Transaction: RZ10)

Copy Subject and issuer values from web dispatcher client certificate and Cloud Connector System Certificate

For following parameter: icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_<x> = SUBJECT="<subject>", ISSUER="<issuer>".

  • Select a free index for <x>.
  • <subject> is the subject of the certificate (example data: CN=SCC, OU=BTP Scenarios, O=Trust Community, C=DE).
  • <issuer> is the issuer of the certificate (example data: CN=MyCompany CA, O=Trust Community, C=DE).

Example: icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_2 = SUBJECT="CN=SCC, OU=BTP Scenarios, O=Trust Community, C=DE", ISSUER="CN=MyCompany CA, O=Trust Community, C=DE".

Parameter name

Value

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_0

Copy subject and issuer values from web dispatcher client certificate

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_1

Copy subject and issuer values from cloud connector system certificate

login/certificate_mapping_rulebased

1

icm/HTTPS/verify_client

1

Step 1.4.d: Set Logon Procedure to “Required with SSL Certificate” for Relevant SICF Services

To access ICF services via certificate logon, make sure that all required ICF services allow Logon Through SSL Certificate as logon method.

Step 2: Configure SAP Web Dispatcher for Principal Propagation

If you are using an intermediate SAP Web Dispatcher to connect to your ABAP backend system, you must set up a trust chain between the involved components Cloud Connector, SAP Web Dispatcher, and ABAP backend system.

We need to Configure SAP Web Dispatcher to trust the Cloud Connector's certificate for identity propagation. Parameters and certificates need to be added.

Make sure your SAP Web Dispatcher supports SSL and configuration done for Web Dispatcher to Forward SSL Certificates for X.509 Authentication. Refer SAP Help documentation for pre-requisites.

Step 2.1: Import Certificates into SAP Web Dispatcher

Below Certificates to be added in web dispatcher PSEs.

  • cloud connector CA certificate in web dispatcher server standard pse (SAPSSLS.pse )
  • s4hana ssl server standard certificate in web dispatcher client pse (SAPSSLC.pse)

Step 2.2: Maintain Required Parameters in Web Dispatcher

Create icm trusted reverse proxy parameters same as we did in Step 1.4.c

Parameter name

Value

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_0

Copy subject and issuer values from cloud connector CA certificate

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_1

Copy subject and issuer values from s4hana ssl server standard certificate

Make sure icm/HTTPS/verify_client parameter is set to 1 (request certificate) or 2 (require certificate). If set to 0, trust cannot be established. The default value is 1, so it is OK if the parameter is not set at all.

Your HTTPS Principal Propagation configuration is now complete for the scenario where a Web Dispatcher is used as an intermediary between the ABAP backend system.

Step 3: Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for RFC using SNC

For enabling Principal Propagation over RFC using Secure Network Communication (SNC), follow the steps below.
If you've already configured HTTPS-based principal propagation on the same S/4HANA system, steps such as certificate generation, trust setup, and user mapping (via STRUST and CERTRULE) may have already been completed. You only need to ensure the SNC-specific configurations.

Make sure SNC setup on the ABAP System is already present. Ensure SAP Cryptographic library is installed as a pre-requisite in cloud connector.

Note: It is important that you use the same SNC implementation on both communication sides. When using the SAP Cryptographic Library, it is recommended that you use an ABAP system SNC identity and a Cloud Connector system identity signed by the same CA for mutual authentication.

Step 3.1: PSE Setup in SAP Cloud Connector for SNC

Step 3.1.a: Login to OS level of SCC then Download and extract the SAP Cryptographic Library. You can refer SAP Help documentation.
Step 3.1.b: Ensure you have set the Environment variables SECUDIR and SNC_LIB

Step 3.1.c: Create SNC PSE at OS level. Navigate to path Crypto and execute below commands

You can Refer SAP Help documentation and below note.

2642538 - How to enable SNC from external programs to ABAP using SAP RFC Connectors

To Create SNC PSE: sapgenpse gen_pse -p SCC.pse "CN=SCC, OU=<name>, O=<name>, C=<name>"

It is recommended that you sign the CSR of PSE with a trusted CA and then import it. Self-signed will also work.

Import Signed Certificate: sapgenpse import_own_cert -p SCC.pse -x <pin> -c SCC.cer -r <RootCA>.cer

Create credentials for the SNC PSE: sapgenpse seclogin -p SCC.pse -O <sccuser>

Note: sccuser is the user under which cloud connector is running.

Adding ABAP SNC certificate in Cloud connector PSE (download from S/4HANA, STRUST --> SNC): sapgenpse maintain_pk -p SCC.pse -a S4HANA.cer

Step 3.1.d: Restart Cloud connector below SNC SECUDIR parameter will appear in Cloud connector UI Configuration tab. (Library path and My name details we need to give).

Once you have created the SNC PSE and imported the required certificates into it, take restart and login to cloud connector UI to define the SNC name

Step 3.2: Generate Certificates in Cloud Connector

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step1.1. You may skip it if the certificates were already generated during the HTTPS setup.)

Step 3.3: Add Certificates to the Trust Store in SCC

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step 1.2. S4hana SSL server standard certificate needs to be added.)

Step 3.4: Synchronize Cloud Trust with Subaccount Identity Provider (IdP)

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step 1.3. You can skip this step if already done.)

Step 3.5: Configure the S/4HANA System for RFC SNC Propagation

Step 3.5.a: Import Certificates into the SSL Server Standard (Transaction: STRUST)

Below certificates needs to be added.

  • cloud connector system certificate imported in S/4HANA SSL server standard
  • cloud connector PSE SNC certificate imported in S/4HANA SNC cryptolib
Step 3.5.b: Define Rule-Based Mapping for the user certificate (Transaction: CERTRULE)

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step 1.4.b. You can skip this step if user mapping has already been configured and login/certificate_mapping_rulebased parameter set to 1)

Step 3.5.c: Configure SNC Identity in the backend system (Transaction: SNC0)

Login to backend ABAP system and execute transaction SNC0 and add cloud connector’s SNC identity. Note the SNC name from SAP Cloud connector.

Step 4: Create System Mappings in SAP Cloud Connector

We need to create Mapping Virtual To Internal System in the Cloud To On-Premise tab for your subaccount in Cloud connector.

Step 4.1: Map HTTPS Connections to SAP Web Dispatcher

Since we are using a Web Dispatcher as an intermediary to the ABAP backend system, we will define the Web Dispatcher host in the HTTPS destination configuration instead of the ABAP system directly. The flow will be like this.

entry.title: Handling API Rate Limit (HTTP 429) Responses in an iFlow using the HTTP receiver adapter
entry.content:
APIs commonly return HTTP 429 (Too Many Requests) when callers exceed rate limits. Historically, handling 429 in SAP iFlows required custom logic (parsing response headers, adding waits or persistence), which introduced complexity around timing and memory management. With the latest HTTP receiver adapter update, you can handle transient 429 responses using configurable retry parameters — reducing custom code and improving reliability.

What is a rate limits in terms of APIs?
Rate limits control how many API calls are allowed per time window, e.g., per second, per minute, per hour, or per day. Limits vary by API and by account. When limits are exceeded, APIs commonly respond with HTTP 429.

These rate limits have their own advantages and disadvantages. We would not be going into the details of these in this blog. We will discuss only on how to handle the error when we get status code 429 in an iflow using HTTP receiver adapter.

Steps to configure the HTTP receiver adapter

  1. Retry Failed Request — enable this option.
  2. HTTP Error Response Codes — add the error codes you want the adapter to retry (e.g., 429 for rate-limiting).
  3. Retry Interval (seconds) — time between retry attempts. Adjust per API and expected recovery time.
  4. Retry Iterations — number of retry attempts. Balance success probability, total wait time, and resource usage.

Suggested example configuration (starter values and to be configured as per your scenarios requirements)

  • HTTP Error Response Codes: 429
  • Retry Interval: 10 seconds
  • Retry Iterations: 5
    Estimated total (fixed-interval) wait: 10s × 5 = 50s (modify if Retry-After or backoff is applied).

 

Enabling retries in the HTTP receiver adapter enables the adapter to re-attempt failed requests per the configured interval and iterations. If retries succeed the iFlow continues; if retries are exhausted the message will fail unless handled by additional iFlow error handling.

For more details on HTTP Receiver Adapter please refer to the documentation : sap-cloud-integration/http-receiver-adapter

entry.title: SAP BTP: Creating Connections at Supply Chain Connect
entry.content:
There’s excitement building in the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) team, as we get ready for the SAP Connect event, which will run from 6-8 October in Las Vegas. Of course, SAP Connect is different this year, with five events offered in one location, where attendees can enjoy a conference experience focused on their own Line of Business. Three of my colleagues have already been busy publishing blogs about SAP BTP topics you’ll be able to find at the conference, ijoaquin on Spend Management, rnoia on HCM and joanneks focusing on technology topics. Not wishing to feel left out, I thought that I would share a blog that focuses on my area of interest, SAP BTP for Supply Chain.

In working with my SAP Supply Chain Management colleagues on topics for the Supply Chain Connect event, we’ve decided to focus on SAP BTP capabilities that go to the heart of a “connected” supply chain, where integration and automation are key to creating agility and resilience. It will be of little surprise therefore that it is these very two topics that will be featured in sessions at the event.

Creating Connections

Integration is key to creating connectivity across supply chain systems and processes, and as such I would like to invite you to join my colleague, Craig Stasila, in two sessions where he will take a look at how SAP Integration Suite might be able to help you create a more connected, and collaborative supply chain:

SCM1886: Optimize your supply chain processes with SAP BTP | 7 Oct, 12:00PM – 12:20PM

In this session Craig will discuss how SAP BTP can help to unlock the potential for creating additional business value across supply chain processes.

SCM2278: Connecting the dots: A collaborative integration workshop | 7 Oct, 3:30PM – 4:45PM

Here Craig will lead an interactive workshop designed to get you thinking about how systems link together and how to get the most out of your approaches to integration. I think you’ll enjoy this one, so don’t miss it!

Automate for Efficiency

Automation and extension are two technology capabilities that can have a dramatic and positive effect on the efficiency, accuracy and productivity of business processes, as you’ll see if you attend this session led by my colleague Loujein Mouammer:

SCM1891 - Reimagine supply chain processes with automation and custom extensions | Oct 8, 12:00PM – 12:20PM

Here Loujein will take you through a demonstration of how automation and extension can help improve operational processes and drive better business outcomes.

Build Your Own Connections with the SAP Team

If you are attending SAP Connect this year, then while I’m sure that you’ll enjoy the SAP BTP sessions delivered by Loujein and Craig, if you are curious to learn more, why not take the opportunity to connect directly with members of the SAP BTP team, and delve into the topics of Integration, Automation and Extensibility a little more deeply. You’ll find the team located at our demo stations on the show floor, and I know that they’ll be excited to speak with you:

CROSS2318 | Connect the enterprise with SAP Integration Suite

CROSS2319 | Create AI agents and apps with SAP Build solutions

Of course if you’re unable to join the live event, then please consider joining the online event and experience SAP Connect Virtual from the comfort of your own office.

However you decide to attend, in-person or online, then I do hope you find SAP Connect to be a truly inspirational and rewarding experience. And of course – enjoy all the SAP BTP sessions!
